long_questions.stem: A benign papillary tumor of the bladder is called a papilloma. Which feature defines papillomas regardless of site?
long_questions.explanation: Papillomas are defined by their papillary (finger-like) histologic pattern, not by location. They are benign epithelial tumors with papillary architecture. Invasion and pleomorphism are malignant features.

long_questions.stem: Which of the following is an example of a papillary tumor found in multiple organ systems?
long_questions.explanation: Papillomas can occur in breast, bladder (urothelial), and nasal mucosa, all sharing papillary histology.

long_questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman has a benign tumor composed of papillary structures lined by normal-appearing epithelial cells. Which of the following best describes this neoplasm?
long_questions.explanation: Papillomas are benign epithelial tumors with papillary fronds. Adenoma refers to benign gland-forming tumors.

long_questions.stem: Which principle explains why a tumor initially sensitive to chemotherapy later becomes resistant?
long_questions.explanation: Clonal evolution produces genetically diverse subclones; resistant clones survive chemotherapy, leading to relapse.

long_questions.stem: Poorly differentiated adenocarcinomas may lack recognizable glands. This reflects loss of:
long_questions.explanation: Differentiation describes how closely tumor cells resemble normal tissue. Poorly differentiated adenocarcinomas may show little to no gland formation.

long_questions.stem: Tripolar mitosis in a neoplastic cell is an example of:
long_questions.explanation: Anaplasia = loss of normal cellular features, including abnormal mitotic figures such as tripolar mitosis.

long_questions.stem: Which of the following best defines dysplasia?

options.B: Reversible change of one adult cell type to another
options.C: Disordered growth with abnormal cells confined to epithelium

long_questions.explanation: Dysplasia is abnormal cell development with nuclear atypia, loss of polarity, and increased mitoses, confined to epithelium. Invasion defines carcinoma.

long_questions.stem: Which of the following is most characteristic of a benign tumor?
long_questions.explanation: Benign tumors grow slowly, are well circumscribed, and resemble normal cells.

long_questions.stem: A fast-growing uterine tumor with variable nuclear size, increased cellularity, and numerous mitoses is most consistent with:
long_questions.explanation: Leiomyosarcoma is malignant, fast-growing, cellular, and shows nuclear pleomorphism with frequent mitoses. Leiomyoma is benign, slow-growing.

long_questions.stem: A tumor described as ‘well circumscribed’ is most likely:
long_questions.explanation: Benign tumors typically have well-defined margins, unlike malignant infiltrative growth.

long_questions.stem: Carcinoma in situ differs from invasive carcinoma by:
long_questions.explanation: Carcinoma in situ shows full-thickness epithelial atypia but basement membrane intact. Invasion occurs once basement membrane is breached.

long_questions.stem: Which cancer most commonly spreads via peritoneal seeding?
long_questions.explanation: Ovarian carcinoma often spreads by seeding the peritoneum.

long_questions.stem: Breast carcinoma often spreads first to which site?
long_questions.explanation: Breast carcinoma commonly metastasizes via lymphatics to axillary nodes first before distant spread.

long_questions.stem: Which mode of metastasis is most characteristic of sarcomas?
long_questions.explanation: Sarcomas spread predominantly via blood (hematogenous). Carcinomas usually spread via lymphatics.

lectures.topic: Genetic Testing for Familial Cancer Syndromes

long_questions.stem: Which of the following best defines an epigenetic change?

options.A: Point mutation in a coding exon
options.B: Truncating mutation in a tumor suppressor

long_questions.explanation: Epigenetic changes are heritable modifications to gene expression without altering DNA sequence, e.g., promoter methylation.

long_questions.stem: A germline mutation in RB1 is classified as:
long_questions.explanation: Germline variants are present in all cells and heritable → hereditary cancer syndrome.

subtopics.name: Germline vs Somatic vs Familial vs Sporadic

long_questions.stem: A patient develops lung cancer after 40 years of smoking. Which category best applies?
long_questions.explanation: Smoking-related lung cancer is a sporadic cancer caused by acquired somatic variants.

long_questions.stem: A germline BRCA1 variant increases cancer risk because:

options.B: One allele is inactivated at birth; second hit occurs later
options.D: It requires multiple somatic mutations in oncogenes
options.E: It is inherited in recessive fashion

long_questions.explanation: Tumor suppressor gene mutations follow the two-hit model: one allele lost in germline, second hit acquired somatically.

long_questions.stem: Which statement is TRUE about oncogenes compared to tumor suppressor genes?

options.A: Oncogenes require both alleles to be mutated
options.B: Oncogenes are usually inactivated by deletions
options.C: Tumor suppressor mutations are usually gain-of-function
options.D: Oncogenes require only one allele activated

long_questions.explanation: Oncogenes require a single gain-of-function mutation; TSGs require both alleles lost (two-hit hypothesis).

long_questions.stem: Which is most often hereditary: oncogene mutations or tumor suppressor gene mutations?
long_questions.explanation: Hereditary syndromes usually involve tumor suppressor gene variants (e.g., BRCA, RB1, APC).

long_questions.stem: Mismatch repair (MMR) deficiency is most strongly associated with:
long_questions.explanation: Lynch syndrome is caused by germline MMR gene mutations (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, EPCAM).

long_questions.stem: BRCA1/2 are primarily involved in which DNA repair pathway?
long_questions.explanation: BRCA1/2 are key mediators of homologous recombination repair of double-strand breaks.

long_questions.stem: Which cancer type is most characteristic of Lynch syndrome?
long_questions.explanation: Lynch syndrome predisposes to colorectal, endometrial, ovarian, urothelial, pancreatic, and prostate cancers.

long_questions.stem: Which molecular feature often characterizes Lynch syndrome tumors?
long_questions.explanation: MSI-H and hypermutator phenotype are hallmarks of Lynch syndrome, making tumors responsive to immunotherapy.

long_questions.stem: A 19-year-old with hundreds of colon polyps is diagnosed with FAP. Which gene is mutated?
long_questions.explanation: FAP is caused by APC mutations (Wnt signaling pathway).

long_questions.stem: Which extracolonic features are associated with FAP?

options.B: Papillary thyroid carcinoma, desmoid tumors, osteomas, CHRPE

long_questions.explanation: FAP can present with desmoids, papillary thyroid carcinoma, calvarial osteomas, and congenital hypertrophic retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE).

long_questions.stem: Which mutation is most strongly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome?
long_questions.explanation: HBOC is most commonly due to BRCA1/2 mutations, impairing homologous recombination repair.

long_questions.stem: Ashkenazi Jewish individuals have higher carrier frequency of:
long_questions.explanation: BRCA1/2 founder variants are common in Ashkenazi Jews (~1 in 40 carriers).

long_questions.stem: A genetic test shows a variant of uncertain significance (VUS). Best next step?
long_questions.explanation: VUS should not guide clinical care or family testing until reclassified. They are managed as benign.

long_questions.stem: The purity of isolated nucleic acids is commonly measured by absorbance at:
long_questions.explanation: DNA and RNA absorb UV light maximally at 260 nm due to aromatic nitrogenous bases.

long_questions.stem: Which reagent is most often used to separate proteins from nucleic acids during extraction?
long_questions.explanation: Chloroform (often with phenol) separates proteins from nucleic acids in organic extraction.

long_questions.stem: Restriction endonucleases recognize and cut:
long_questions.explanation: Restriction enzymes cut at palindromic sequences, generating blunt or sticky ends.

long_questions.stem: Polyacrylamide gels are preferred over agarose gels when:
long_questions.explanation: Polyacrylamide gels have higher resolution and can distinguish fragments differing by a single base.

long_questions.stem: What is the main product of reverse transcription?
long_questions.explanation: Reverse transcriptase copies mRNA into cDNA, lacking introns and regulatory regions.

long_questions.stem: PCR requires knowledge of:
long_questions.explanation: Primers must be complementary to sequences flanking the DNA segment of interest.

long_questions.stem: RT-PCR differs from PCR by requiring:
long_questions.explanation: RT-PCR begins with RNA, which is reverse transcribed into cDNA before amplification.

long_questions.stem: Southern blotting detects:
long_questions.explanation: Southern blot: DNA. Northern: RNA. Western: Protein. Southwestern: DNA-binding proteins.

long_questions.stem: Which probe is used in Western blotting?
long_questions.explanation: Western blots use antibodies to detect specific proteins.

long_questions.stem: The Sanger sequencing method relies on the use of:
long_questions.explanation: Dideoxynucleotides (ddNTPs) terminate chain elongation, generating fragments for size-based sequencing.

long_questions.stem: Whole-exome sequencing focuses on:
long_questions.explanation: Whole-exome sequencing targets protein-coding exons (~2% of genome), capturing most disease-causing mutations.

long_questions.stem: Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) is based on:

options.C: Presence or absence of restriction enzyme cut sites

long_questions.explanation: RFLP analysis detects polymorphisms that alter restriction sites, changing fragment lengths after digestion.

long_questions.stem: Short tandem repeat (STR) analysis is useful for:
long_questions.explanation: STR analysis examines repeat numbers in microsatellite DNA, useful for identity and parentage testing.

long_questions.stem: Which viral vector is most commonly used for long-term gene expression in dividing and non-dividing cells?
long_questions.explanation: Lentiviral vectors (HIV-derived) integrate into host genome and infect both dividing and non-dividing cells. Widely used in gene therapy.

long_questions.stem: Exon-skipping therapy using antisense oligonucleotides can restore partial function in which condition?
long_questions.explanation: Exon skipping can convert Duchenne (out-of-frame mutation) into Becker muscular dystrophy (in-frame), producing partially functional dystrophin.

long_questions.stem: The short arm of a chromosome is designated as:
long_questions.explanation: The short arm is 'p' (petite), while 'q' is the long arm.

long_questions.stem: Which phase of mitosis is typically arrested for chromosome visualization in karyotyping?
long_questions.explanation: Karyotyping examines metaphase chromosomes arrested with colchicine, when they are most condensed and visible.

long_questions.stem: Chromosomes with centromeres near the end, such as 13, 14, 15, 21, 22, are called:
long_questions.explanation: Acrocentric chromosomes have very short p arms and long q arms; common sites of Robertsonian translocations.

long_questions.stem: Which karyotype represents Down syndrome in a male?
long_questions.explanation: Down syndrome = trisomy 21. Males are 47, XY, +21; females 47, XX, +21.

long_questions.stem: A newborn has hypotonia, simian crease, and Brushfield spots. Which complication is most likely?
long_questions.explanation: Congenital heart defects (e.g., endocardial cushion defects) are common in Down syndrome, along with GI atresias and leukemia risk.

long_questions.stem: Characteristic hand finding in Edwards syndrome:
long_questions.explanation: Edwards syndrome = clenched fist with overlapping fingers, rocker-bottom feet, micrognathia, congenital heart disease.

long_questions.stem: Which congenital anomaly is strongly associated with Patau syndrome?
long_questions.explanation: Patau syndrome commonly presents with cleft lip/palate, polydactyly, severe intellectual disability, congenital heart disease.

long_questions.stem: Most cases of trisomy 21 are caused by:
long_questions.explanation: 95% of Down syndrome is due to meiotic nondisjunction, usually maternal meiosis I.

long_questions.stem: Robertsonian translocations involve fusion of:
long_questions.explanation: Robertsonian translocations occur between acrocentric chromosomes (13, 14, 15, 21, 22).

long_questions.stem: A ring chromosome results from:

options.B: Loss of one arm and duplication of the other
options.C: Deletion of both telomeres with end fusion
options.E: Insertion of a segment into another chromosome

long_questions.explanation: Ring chromosomes form when both ends lose telomeres and fuse, often causing instability.

long_questions.stem: A newborn with a high-pitched cry, hypertelorism, and severe intellectual disability most likely has which cytogenetic abnormality?
long_questions.explanation: Cri-du-chat syndrome is due to a terminal deletion on chromosome 5p.

long_questions.stem: 22q11 microdeletion is associated with:
long_questions.explanation: 22q11 deletion causes DiGeorge (thymic hypoplasia, hypocalcemia, congenital heart disease).

long_questions.stem: Which FISH probe is most appropriate for detecting trisomy 21?
long_questions.explanation: Centromere probes identify chromosome number; useful for aneuploidy detection such as trisomy 21.

long_questions.stem: Which statement about FISH is correct?

options.C: Uses fluorescent probes to hybridize DNA sequences

long_questions.explanation: FISH uses fluorescent DNA probes, works on interphase and metaphase nuclei, and can detect microdeletions invisible to karyotype.

subtopics.name: Cancer Incidence and Mortality by Sex

long_questions.stem: What is the most common cancer in women worldwide?
long_questions.explanation: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women globally. Lung cancer is the most deadly.

long_questions.stem: Which cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in women?
long_questions.explanation: Lung cancer is the most common cause of cancer death in women, even though breast cancer is more common.

long_questions.stem: What is the most common cancer in men?
long_questions.explanation: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men. Lung cancer is the deadliest.

long_questions.stem: Which cancer is the most common cause of cancer-related death in men?
long_questions.explanation: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in men, followed by prostate and colorectal cancers.

long_questions.stem: Cancer epidemiology shows that most deaths are caused by:
long_questions.explanation: Mortality is linked to cancers with high metastatic potential and late diagnosis (e.g., lung, pancreatic).

long_questions.stem: Which is a correct statement about US cancer screening impact?

options.A: Screening has eliminated breast cancer deaths
options.B: Lung cancer mortality remains high despite screening
options.C: Colorectal screening has no impact on survival
options.D: Cervical cancer incidence has increased due to screening
options.E: Screening guarantees cure in all cancers

long_questions.explanation: Lung cancer mortality is still high due to late-stage detection and aggressive biology, even with screening.

long_questions.stem: Carcinogenesis is primarily driven by:
long_questions.explanation: Carcinogenesis arises from genetic mutations in DNA. Epigenetic and metabolic changes are secondary.

long_questions.stem: A cancer with a clonal origin later displays heterogeneous phenotypes. This reflects:
long_questions.explanation: Clonal evolution leads to heterogeneity, explaining varied behavior and drug resistance in cancers.

long_questions.stem: Which molecule is the common precursor for both purine and pyrimidine nucleotide synthesis?
long_questions.explanation: PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate) is the activated ribose donor for both purine and pyrimidine biosynthesis.

long_questions.stem: PRPP synthetase is inhibited by:
long_questions.explanation: Purine and pyrimidine nucleotides (ADP, GDP) feedback inhibit PRPP synthetase, preventing overproduction.

long_questions.stem: Which enzyme is the rate-limiting step of de novo purine synthesis?
long_questions.explanation: Glutamine-PRPP amidotransferase is the committed, regulated step in purine synthesis.

long_questions.stem: Which nutrient deficiency impairs de novo purine synthesis, causing megaloblastic anemia?
long_questions.explanation: Folate derivatives donate one-carbon units in purine biosynthesis; deficiency reduces nucleotide synthesis.

long_questions.stem: Which enzyme salvages hypoxanthine and guanine?
long_questions.explanation: HGPRT (hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase) salvages purine bases using PRPP.

long_questions.stem: APRT salvages which base?
long_questions.explanation: APRT (adenine phosphoribosyl transferase) salvages adenine → AMP.

long_questions.stem: What is the final product of purine degradation in humans?
long_questions.explanation: Uric acid is the end product of purine degradation in humans.

long_questions.stem: Xanthine oxidase deficiency leads to accumulation of:
long_questions.explanation: Xanthine oxidase deficiency causes xanthinuria with xanthine/hypoxanthine accumulation but low uric acid.

long_questions.stem: A boy with self-mutilating behavior and hyperuricemia most likely has deficiency of:
long_questions.explanation: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome results from near-absent HGPRT, causing hyperuricemia and neurologic symptoms.

long_questions.stem: Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency leads to:
long_questions.explanation: ADA deficiency causes SCID due to toxic accumulation of dATP inhibiting ribonucleotide reductase.

long_questions.stem: What is the committed step in pyrimidine synthesis?

options.B: Carbamoyl phosphate synthesis by CPS II

long_questions.explanation: CPS II in cytosol (glutamine → carbamoyl phosphate) is the rate-limiting step in pyrimidine synthesis.

long_questions.stem: A child with megaloblastic anemia unresponsive to B12/folate supplementation has high urinary orotic acid but no hyperammonemia. Diagnosis?
long_questions.explanation: Hereditary orotic aciduria results from UMP synthase deficiency. Orotic acid accumulates, but no hyperammonemia is present.

long_questions.stem: A patient with elevated orotic acid and hyperammonemia likely has:
long_questions.explanation: OTC deficiency (urea cycle disorder) causes increased carbamoyl phosphate → excess orotic acid, with hyperammonemia.

long_questions.stem: Ribonucleotide reductase is inhibited by:
long_questions.explanation: Ribonucleotide reductase is activated by ATP and inhibited by dATP — explains SCID in ADA deficiency.

long_questions.stem: 6-mercaptopurine is activated by:
long_questions.explanation: HGPRT activates 6-MP to thio-IMP, which inhibits purine synthesis.

long_questions.stem: 5-fluorouracil inhibits which enzyme?
long_questions.explanation: 5-FU forms 5-fdUMP, irreversibly inhibiting thymidylate synthase, blocking dTMP synthesis.

long_questions.stem: Methotrexate inhibits:
long_questions.explanation: Methotrexate inhibits DHFR, preventing regeneration of THF, thus blocking purine and thymidylate synthesis.

long_questions.stem: Hydroxyurea inhibits which enzyme?
long_questions.explanation: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase → decreased DNA synthesis; also ↑ HbF for sickle cell therapy.

long_questions.stem: Which translocation is most associated with follicular lymphoma?
long_questions.explanation: Follicular lymphoma is caused by t(14;18), placing Bcl2 under the Ig heavy-chain promoter → apoptosis resistance.

long_questions.stem: Overexpression of Bcl2 leads to:
long_questions.explanation: Bcl2 blocks intrinsic apoptosis → cells survive longer, leading to multidrug resistance.

long_questions.stem: The Philadelphia chromosome results from which translocation?
long_questions.explanation: Philadelphia chromosome = t(9;22), creating BCR-ABL fusion gene with constitutive tyrosine kinase activity.

long_questions.stem: The abnormal protein product of the Philadelphia chromosome is best described as:
long_questions.explanation: BCR-ABL encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase → drives CML pathogenesis.

long_questions.stem: Genomic instability in cancers is most often caused by loss of:
long_questions.explanation: Loss of p53 or Rb removes cell cycle checkpoints, leading to mutations, gene amplifications, and aneuploidy.

long_questions.stem: Double minutes (dmin) represent:
long_questions.explanation: Double minutes are small circular extrachromosomal DNA fragments that often carry amplified oncogenes.

long_questions.stem: Homogeneously staining regions (HSRs) are best described as:
long_questions.explanation: HSRs represent intrachromosomal regions of amplified DNA without normal banding.

long_questions.stem: Cyclin D1 amplification is associated with:
long_questions.explanation: Cyclin D1 amplification → breast and bladder cancers. Leads to unchecked G1→S transition.

long_questions.stem: MDM2 amplification is most associated with:
long_questions.explanation: MDM2 amplification → sarcomas. MDM2 promotes p53 degradation, removing cell cycle control.

long_questions.stem: MYCN amplification is strongly associated with:
long_questions.explanation: MYCN amplification is seen in ~25% of neuroblastomas and indicates poor prognosis.

long_questions.stem: HER2/neu amplification is present in ~20% of:
long_questions.explanation: HER2/neu amplification occurs in ~15–30% of breast cancers, guiding therapy with trastuzumab.

long_questions.stem: Which drug targets the BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase in CML?
long_questions.explanation: Imatinib (Gleevec) inhibits the BCR-ABL fusion protein → cornerstone therapy for CML.

long_questions.stem: Which drug targets HER2/neu amplification in breast cancer?
long_questions.explanation: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody against HER2/neu → effective in HER2+ breast cancer.

long_questions.stem: Which is a prerequisite for an effective population cancer screening program?

options.A: The disease must lack a latent period
options.B: The test should have high sensitivity and specificity
options.C: There should be no available treatment
options.D: The disease must be extremely rare

long_questions.explanation: Effective screening requires high sensitivity/specificity, an identifiable latent stage, and an effective treatment.

long_questions.stem: For breast cancer, how long does it typically take for a single cancer cell to become clinically detectable without additional mutations?
long_questions.explanation: It takes ~5 years and ~30 doublings for breast cancer to become palpable if undetected.

long_questions.stem: A highly sensitive test has the ability to:

options.C: Rule out disease with positive results

long_questions.explanation: Sensitivity = true positives / (true positives + false negatives). High sensitivity → few false negatives.

long_questions.stem: A highly specific test has the ability to:
long_questions.explanation: Specificity = true negatives / (true negatives + false positives). High specificity → few false positives.

long_questions.stem: Positive predictive value depends most on:
long_questions.explanation: PPV increases with higher disease prevalence. NPV decreases as prevalence rises.

long_questions.stem: Lead-time bias refers to:

options.A: Longer survival due to slower-growing cancers
options.B: Earlier diagnosis without changing death outcome

long_questions.explanation: Lead-time bias: survival seems longer because diagnosis is earlier, but overall life span unchanged.

long_questions.stem: Length-time bias in screening means:

options.A: Fast-growing cancers are more likely to be detected
options.B: Slow-growing cancers are more likely to be detected

long_questions.explanation: Length-time bias: screening preferentially detects indolent cancers, missing aggressive ones.

long_questions.stem: According to ACS, women should begin annual mammograms at age:
long_questions.explanation: ACS: annual mammograms from age 40. USPSTF recommends biennial screening age 40–74.

long_questions.stem: USPSTF recommends breast cancer screening how often for women 40–74?
long_questions.explanation: USPSTF: biennial mammograms for women 40–74.

long_questions.stem: Which is NOT recommended by USPSTF for breast cancer screening?
long_questions.explanation: USPSTF recommends against BSE due to risk of harm from false positives.

long_questions.stem: NCCN recommends lung cancer screening in patients:

options.C: Age 50–80, >20 pack-years, current or quit <15 years

long_questions.explanation: High-risk: 50–80 yo, >20 pack-years, current or quit <15 years. Annual low-dose CT recommended.

long_questions.stem: Which biopsy method is least invasive?
long_questions.explanation: Fine-needle aspiration is least invasive but provides limited cytology only.

long_questions.stem: Which diagnostic tool can help determine tumor tissue of origin when histology and IHC are inconclusive?
long_questions.explanation: NGS and AI-based classifiers can suggest tissue of origin when traditional pathology is uncertain.

long_questions.stem: Which surgical approach removes the entire tumor with normal margins for cure?
long_questions.explanation: Definitive/curative surgery = tumor resection with margins. Cytoreductive debulks but leaves residual disease.

long_questions.stem: Cytoreductive surgery is performed to:

options.B: Debulk tumor and improve chemo/radiation efficacy

long_questions.explanation: Cytoreduction reduces tumor burden, allowing adjuvant therapies to be more effective.

long_questions.stem: Which of the following is an example of prophylactic surgery?
long_questions.explanation: High-risk patients (FAP, BRCA mutations) benefit from prophylactic colectomy or mastectomy/oophorectomy.

long_questions.stem: Which of the following best describes the bystander effect of radiation?

options.B: Nearby unirradiated cells are affected by signals from irradiated cells
options.C: Cells in G0 phase are most sensitive
options.D: DNA repair is enhanced in irradiated cells

long_questions.explanation: Bystander effect = irradiated cells release signals (ROS, cytokines) that damage nearby unirradiated cells.

long_questions.stem: Which of the '5 R's of radiobiology' refers to killing hypoxic cells by reoxygenating tumor core?
long_questions.explanation: Reoxygenation improves killing of hypoxic tumor cells by making them more radiosensitive.

long_questions.stem: Which is a late complication of radiation therapy?
long_questions.explanation: Late toxicities include secondary malignancies (e.g., leukemia), infertility, fibrosis. Acute = fatigue, mucositis, hair loss.

long_questions.stem: Which drug class is cell cycle nonspecific and works in G0?
long_questions.explanation: Alkylating agents (cyclophosphamide, cisplatin) are nonspecific, damaging DNA in all phases.

long_questions.stem: A patient receiving chemotherapy develops fever and neutropenia. Best next step?
long_questions.explanation: Neutropenic fever is a medical emergency. Immediate empiric IV broad-spectrum antibiotics are required.

long_questions.stem: Tumor lysis syndrome causes all EXCEPT:
long_questions.explanation: Tumor lysis = ↑ uric acid, K, phosphate; ↓ Ca (precipitates with phosphate). Hypernatremia is not typical.

long_questions.stem: 5-fluorouracil inhibits:
long_questions.explanation: 5-FU → 5-fdUMP → irreversible inhibition of thymidylate synthase.

long_questions.stem: Methotrexate toxicity is reduced by giving:
long_questions.explanation: Leucovorin rescues normal cells from MTX-induced folate depletion.

long_questions.stem: Paclitaxel works by:
long_questions.explanation: Taxanes stabilize microtubules, freezing mitosis in metaphase.

long_questions.stem: Bevacizumab targets:
long_questions.explanation: Bevacizumab is anti-VEGF, inhibiting angiogenesis.

long_questions.stem: Imatinib is effective in CML because it inhibits:
long_questions.explanation: Imatinib blocks BCR-ABL, a constitutive tyrosine kinase from t(9;22).

long_questions.stem: Tamoxifen is a:
long_questions.explanation: Tamoxifen is an ER antagonist in breast, partial agonist in bone/uterus.

long_questions.stem: Ipilimumab targets which immune checkpoint?
long_questions.explanation: Ipilimumab is anti–CTLA-4, enhancing T-cell activation.

long_questions.stem: Which hallmark of cancer involves the ability to evade apoptosis?
long_questions.explanation: Cancer cells upregulate anti-apoptotic proteins like Bcl2, allowing survival despite DNA damage.

long_questions.stem: Which hallmark allows tumors to spread to distant organs?
long_questions.explanation: Metastasis is the spread of tumor cells to distant organs, a major cause of cancer mortality.

long_questions.stem: Which emerging hallmark involves tumor cells avoiding recognition by the immune system?
long_questions.explanation: Immune evasion is a key mechanism where tumors express PD-L1 or recruit Tregs to suppress immunity.

long_questions.stem: Which checkpoint is most affected by loss of p53?
long_questions.explanation: p53 induces p21 to block G1/S transition. Mutation = unchecked DNA replication.

long_questions.stem: Cyclin D overexpression promotes cancer by:
long_questions.explanation: Cyclin D-CDK4/6 phosphorylates Rb → releases E2F → uncontrolled G1/S progression.

long_questions.stem: Which FDA-approved drugs directly inhibit CDK4/6 in HR+, HER2- breast cancer?
long_questions.explanation: CDK4/6 inhibitors block G1/S transition and improve survival in ER+ breast cancer.

long_questions.stem: Which caspase is an executioner caspase in apoptosis?
long_questions.explanation: Caspase 3 (and 7) are executioner caspases that cleave structural proteins and DNA repair enzymes.

long_questions.stem: Activation of cytochrome c release from mitochondria occurs in which apoptosis pathway?
long_questions.explanation: Intrinsic (mitochondrial) pathway involves BAX/BAK opening pores, releasing cytochrome c → caspase 9.

long_questions.stem: Resistance to apoptosis in follicular lymphoma is due to overexpression of:
long_questions.explanation: t(14;18) → Bcl-2 overexpression → inhibition of intrinsic apoptosis → lymphoma survival.

long_questions.stem: Normal somatic cells senesce after ~50 divisions due to:
long_questions.explanation: Somatic cells lack telomerase, so telomeres shorten each division until senescence occurs.

long_questions.stem: Telomerase is most active in:
long_questions.explanation: Cancer cells maintain immortality by upregulating telomerase, preserving chromosome ends.

long_questions.stem: Cancer cells preferentially use aerobic glycolysis because:

options.A: It produces more ATP per glucose

long_questions.explanation: Warburg effect: glycolysis provides intermediates for nucleotides, lipids, and proteins, even if ATP yield is low.

long_questions.stem: IDH1 mutations produce which oncometabolite?
long_questions.explanation: Mutant IDH converts α-ketoglutarate into 2-HG, inhibiting DNA repair enzymes → oncogenesis.

long_questions.stem: Cancer cachexia is primarily mediated by:
long_questions.explanation: Cachexia = systemic inflammation mediated by IL-6, TNF-α → muscle breakdown, anorexia, wasting.

long_questions.stem: Which factor is the major driver of tumor angiogenesis?
long_questions.explanation: VEGF drives endothelial proliferation and neovascularization in tumors.

long_questions.stem: Resistance to bevacizumab often occurs because tumors:
long_questions.explanation: Tumors bypass VEGF inhibition by upregulating alternative pro-angiogenic factors (FGF, PDGF).

long_questions.stem: The first step in metastasis requires:
long_questions.explanation: Tumors need angiogenesis to enable invasion and spread.

long_questions.stem: Which concept explains organ-specific metastasis (e.g., breast cancer to bone)?
long_questions.explanation: Seed and soil hypothesis = tumor cells (seed) preferentially colonize organs (soil) with favorable environment.

long_questions.stem: Tumors expressing PD-L1 inhibit:
long_questions.explanation: PD-L1 on tumor binds PD-1 on T-cells → exhaustion, preventing cytotoxic activity.

long_questions.stem: CAR-T therapy failures often occur due to:
long_questions.explanation: CAR-T often fails from tumor antigen loss and T-cell exhaustion, limiting long-term efficacy.

long_questions.stem: Which term describes tailoring treatment to a patient based on their genetic and molecular tumor profile?
long_questions.explanation: Precision medicine uses patient-specific tumor biology (mutations, biomarkers) to guide therapy.

long_questions.stem: Stratified medicine differs from precision medicine by:

options.B: Treating all patients the same way

long_questions.explanation: Stratified medicine groups patients by biomarkers (e.g., PD-L1+ vs PD-L1–) to predict response.

long_questions.stem: Which of the following is a predictive biomarker for trastuzumab therapy?
long_questions.explanation: Trastuzumab is effective in HER2-amplified breast cancer.

long_questions.stem: Liquid biopsy primarily analyzes:

options.B: Circulating tumor DNA and circulating tumor cells

long_questions.explanation: Liquid biopsy detects ctDNA and CTCs in blood, useful for monitoring tumor burden and mutations.

long_questions.stem: PD-L1 expression testing is used to guide therapy with:
long_questions.explanation: PD-L1 positivity predicts response to anti–PD-1 therapy (pembrolizumab, nivolumab).

long_questions.stem: Patients with thiopurine methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency are at increased risk of toxicity from:
long_questions.explanation: TPMT metabolizes 6-MP and azathioprine. Deficiency → bone marrow toxicity at normal doses.

long_questions.stem: Patients with DPD (dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase) deficiency risk severe toxicity from:
long_questions.explanation: DPD deficiency prevents 5-FU breakdown → life-threatening toxicity.

long_questions.stem: UGT1A1*28 polymorphism increases risk of neutropenia and diarrhea with:
long_questions.explanation: UGT1A1 glucuronidates SN-38, the active metabolite of irinotecan. Mutation → toxicity.

long_questions.stem: CAR-T therapy works by:

options.B: Engineering patient T-cells with chimeric antigen receptors

long_questions.explanation: CAR-T = patient T-cells are modified to express CARs targeting tumor antigens.

long_questions.stem: A major life-threatening toxicity of CAR-T therapy is:
long_questions.explanation: CAR-T often causes cytokine release syndrome (CRS), with fever, hypotension, multi-organ dysfunction.

long_questions.stem: Tumor-infiltrating lymphocyte (TIL) therapy differs from CAR-T in that:

options.A: TIL uses expanded patient lymphocytes naturally infiltrating tumors
options.C: TIL is only used in leukemia
options.D: TIL relies exclusively on NK cells

long_questions.explanation: TIL expands naturally occurring tumor-reactive T-cells ex vivo, unlike engineered CAR-T.

long_questions.stem: Oncotype Dx is primarily used for:

options.A: Risk stratification in acute myeloid leukemia

long_questions.explanation: Oncotype Dx scores breast cancer recurrence risk, guiding adjuvant therapy decisions.

long_questions.stem: Which is TRUE about targeted therapies vs traditional chemotherapy?

options.B: Targeted therapies are usually cytostatic, not cytotoxic
options.C: Targeted therapies have no side effects

long_questions.explanation: Targeted drugs block proliferation pathways (cytostatic). Chemo is cytotoxic but less specific.

long_questions.stem: The primary purpose of genetic counseling is to:

options.B: Educate and guide patients about genetic risk

long_questions.explanation: Genetic counseling provides education, risk assessment, and informed decision-making support.

long_questions.stem: Which family history pattern most strongly suggests a hereditary cancer syndrome?

options.A: One distant relative with prostate cancer at age 80
options.B: Two siblings with lung cancer, both heavy smokers
options.C: Multiple close relatives with the same or related cancers at young ages
options.D: One grandparent with colon cancer at age 85

long_questions.explanation: Clustering of early-onset, related cancers in close relatives strongly suggests hereditary cancer.

long_questions.stem: Most hereditary cancer syndromes (BRCA, Lynch, FAP) are inherited in which pattern?
long_questions.explanation: Most hereditary cancer syndromes are autosomal dominant with variable penetrance.

long_questions.stem: Which concept explains why not all individuals with BRCA1 mutation develop breast cancer?
long_questions.explanation: Incomplete penetrance = not every mutation carrier expresses the disease phenotype.

long_questions.stem: NCCN recommends germline testing for which of the following patients?

options.A: Breast cancer diagnosed at age 65 with no family history
options.B: Triple-negative breast cancer diagnosed before age 60

long_questions.explanation: NCCN: TNBC ≤ 60 years, ovarian cancer at any age, colon cancer ≤ 50 years, or multiple affected relatives → test.

long_questions.stem: A patient with colon cancer at 48 and a sibling with endometrial cancer at 45 meets criteria for testing for:
long_questions.explanation: NCCN recommends MMR gene testing for patients with CRC <50 or with related cancers (endometrial).

long_questions.stem: A Variant of Uncertain Significance (VUS) in BRCA2 should be managed as:
long_questions.explanation: VUS should not guide clinical decisions. Reclassification is needed before use.

long_questions.stem: The Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) prevents:

options.A: Life insurance companies from using genetic info
options.B: Employers and health insurers from discriminating based on genetic results
options.E: Disclosure of results to family members

long_questions.explanation: GINA (2008) prevents employment and health insurance discrimination, but not life/disability insurance restrictions.

long_questions.stem: Which counseling approach is emphasized when disclosing cancer genetic risk?
long_questions.explanation: Genetic counseling is non-directive: patients are supported in making informed personal choices.
